There appeared then to be two main points 
to be kept in view in <s>investigating <\s> examining 
the Salpae - 1stly Are the statements made 
by Chamisso correct? and 2ndly If they
be correct, how far is the “Alternation Theory “
a just and sufficient generalization of 
the phenomena?
These questions, however, could not be entered 
upon without a thorough preliminary study 
of the structure of the Salpae  - the opportunities 
for which are granted but to few.
Such opportunities, <s>however <\s>, were afforded 
to the writer of the present paper at Cape York,
in November 1849: for a time, the sea was 
absolutely crowded with Salpae, in all states 
of growth and of a size very convenient for 
examination - At infrequent periods 
the writer had occasion, repeatedly, to [text?] <s>[text?]<\s>
The results at which he had arrived 
and to find strong analogical confirmation 
in the structure of Pyrosoma and other allied 
genera -*
* Those who are acquainted with the nature of the service 
on which HMS “Rattlesnake “ was engaged will readily 
comprehend that the author’s investigations were 
almost <u>necessarily <\u> original and independent of 
anything going on in Europe.
It is the more necessary to state this - as it will 
be seen in the historical part of this paper that 
M Krohn in the Ann. des Sciences for 1846 has completely 
anticipated the chief results <s>at which the author 
[text?]<\s> arrived at
